summary: Email correspondence between the U.S. Attorney's Office and the chambers of Judge Alison J. Nathan regarding a redaction error in a court filing (Dkt. No. 453) in the Ghislaine Maxwell case. The government requests the filing be temporarily removed so a corrected version can be submitted, as a witness's name was inadvertently revealed.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The Honorable Judge whose chambers are being communicated with regarding the correction of a court filing with a redaction error.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The subject of the court filing (Dkt. No. 453) which contains the redaction error; her name appears in the corrected redactions document title.

connections.description: Judge Nathan is presiding over the criminal case against defendant Ghislaine Maxwell, as indicated by the correspondence regarding a filing in her case.

events.title: Redaction Error Correction Request
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office alerts Judge Nathan's chambers that a court filing (Dkt. No. 453) in the Ghislaine Maxwell case contains a redaction error where a witness's name is visible. They request the filing be temporarily removed from ECF to submit a corrected version.

locations: 1 Saint Andrews Plaza, New York, New York 10007
keyFacts: A court filing (Dkt. No. 453) in the Ghislaine Maxwell case contained a redaction error, inadvertently revealing the name of a witness.
The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York requested the court remove the filing from the electronic docket (ECF) to allow submission of a corrected version.
The correspondence is addressed to the chambers of Judge Alison J. Nathan, who was presiding over the Maxwell case.
The corrected document's filename references a reply in support of motions in limine for Maxwell, dated October 27, 2021.
